STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 27, 2021
Carol Kehoe
Ingham County DHHS
P. O. Box 30088
Lansing, MI 48909
RE: License #: CP330201190
Ingham County DHHS
5303 S Cedar Street
Lansing, MI 48909
Dear Ms. Kehoe:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 10/14/2021.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP330201190
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Ingham County DHHS
Facility Address: 5303 S Cedar Street
Lansing, MI 48909
Facility Telephone #: (517) 887-9791
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1991
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
1

Date of On-site Inspection: 10/14/2021

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
One of eight foster home files held a special evaluation that went beyond 45 days
and did not have written notification to the foster parent.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three of eleven foster care and independent living files did not meet this
requirement.
File one: A USP due on 7/30/21 was completed on 8/2/21.
File two: A USP due on 2/2/21 was completed on 2/10/21.
File three: A USP due on 7/13/21 was completed on 7/26/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
11/27/19 INTERIM review, CAP approved 12/12/19
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
4

One of eight foster care files did not have a foster home visit documented for
February 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
11/18/20 RENEWAL review, CAP approved 12/21/20
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
Four case files did not have documentation of the program statement being provided
to the youth prior to entering IL.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
Four case files did not have documentation that policies and procedures were
provided to the youth prior to entering IL.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
Three of three independent living files did not have documentation that the youth’s
budget was reviewed on a monthly basis.
File one and two: There were no monthly budgets uploaded.
File three: Monthly budgets were missing for December 2020 and March through
July 2021.
R 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
care provided shall be documented in the youth's record.
R400.12413 (2) An agency shall have documentation from the
medical or dental provider of all medical and dental care
received by a foster child.
5

Three of three independent living files did not have medical/dental documentation as
required.
File one indicated a medical occurred on 9/30/20. However, an accompanying
medical form was not uploaded.
File two indicated a dental occurred on 7/23/20. However, an accompanying form
was not uploaded.
File three indicated a dental occurred on 2/22/20. However, an accompanying form
was not uploaded.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 801-01 Health Requirements
Page 3
Dental examinations are required for children one year of age
and older, as follows:
 A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every
six months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Two of eight foster care files held late dental exams.
File one: A dental exam occurred on 5/17/21, with the prior exam being in 2019.
File two: A current dental is not on file. The last dental exam was 9/3/20.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Page 3-4
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables…
 Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
 Within 30 calendar days after the youth’s 14th birthday
and every six months thereafter.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
6

Ten of eleven foster care and independent living files did not meet this requirement.
File one: The 4/30/21 and 8/2/21 USPs did not have an FTM within 30 days prior to
the report. In addition, a semi-annual transition plan (SATP) FTM was due in March
2021 and has not been completed.
File two: The 2/10/21 and 4/27/21 USPs did not have an FTM within 30 days prior.
File three: The 1/14/21, 4/13/21, 7/1/21 and 9/23/21 USPs did not have FTMs.
File four: The 8/10/21 FTM did not have an 1105 report completed. The 6/1/21 FTM
had an 1105 with a blank signature page and no indication of who attended.
File five: The 9/24/21 USP did not have an FTM within 30 days prior.
File six: The DHHS-901 form for the 6/14/21 SATP was not completed.
File seven: The 5/1/21 and 7/30/21 USPs did not have FTMs within 30 days prior.
File eight: The 6/2/21 USP did not have an FTM 30 days prior.
File nine: The 1/29/21 and 4/29/21 FTMs did not have 1105 reports. The 9/13/21
FTM did not have the youth’s signature. The 4/27/21 and 6/28/21 USPs did not have
FTMs 30 days prior to the report.
File ten: The last SATP occurred on 10/17/20; a new one was due in April 2021. The
10/17/20 SATP did not have the youth, worker, or foster parent signature.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
11/18/20 RENEWAL review, CAP approved 12/21/20
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Ten of eleven foster care and independent living files did not have case contacts
documented within the required time frames. Contacts were observed to be entered
between 1-60 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
11/18/20 RENEWAL review, CAP approved 12/21/20
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 17
The caseworker must meet with their supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every assigned case.
7

Two of eight foster care files did not have monthly supervision documented as
required.
File one: Supervision was not documented for October 2020; April or August 2021.
File two: Supervision was not documented for January, February, April, July, or
August 2021. The agency reported that supervision occurred, but it was not entered
in MiSACWIS by the supervisor, who is no longer with the agency.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Pages 9-10
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker.
• Supervisor.
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed apart.
• Parents who are a member of a participating household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
CI 17-099
All treatment plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or later
must have signatures from all appropriate case members within
30 days of the report date.
Eight of eleven foster care and independent living case files did not meet this
requirement.
File one: The 4/30/21 PATP did not have signatures from the parent or foster parent.
File two: The 2/2/21 USP and PATP did not have signature pages uploaded.
File three: The 6/3/21 PATP was signed by the parent outside of the 30-day
requirement.
File four: The 3/18/21, 6/7/21 and 8/19/21 PATPs did not have the youth’s signature.
The 8/19/21 PATP did not have the parent signature.
File five: The 1/29/21 PATP did not have the parent signature.
File six: The 7/26/21 USP had a late youth signature on 9/14/21.
File seven: The 7/30/21 PATP did not have the youth’s signature.
File eight: The 2/5/21, 4/27/21, 6/28/21 and 9/26/21 PATPs did not have youth or
foster parent signatures.
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
Page 3
Prior to a planned placement change, or within three business
days of an emergency placement change, the caseworker must
document…
8

Three of eleven foster care and independent living files did not meet this
requirement.
File one: Three DHHS-69 forms were due in August 2021 due to a child’s placement
change. The forms were not completed until 10/12/21.
File two: The youth moved on 1/8/20. A DHHS-69 was not completed until 1/15/20.
File three: The youth moved on 11/19/20. A DHHS-69 was not completed until
2/24/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED: Previously cited as 722-09C.
11/18/20 RENEWAL review, CAP approved 12/21/20.
FOM 722-06I Maintaining Connections: Parenting Time, Sibling Visitation
Pages 10-11 and Contact
Siblings in foster care who are not placed together must have
regular contact. At minimum, siblings placed apart must have
one in-person contact within the first 30 days of the placement
that results in separation and one in-person contact per
calendar month thereafter.
All exceptions must be recorded in MiSACWIS. The caseworker
must document reasonable efforts to ensure in-person sibling
contacts in the case service plan.
One of eight foster care files did not have documentation of regular sibling visits. The
USP indicated visits should be twice weekly. However, only one sibling visit was
documented during this review period. An exception was not completed in
MiSACWIS.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Pages 2-3
The health screens within the MiSACWIS Health Profile section
must be updated quarterly to ensure the child's current health
information is up-to-date and accurate.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
o Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
o At reunification.
o The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement. Quarterly.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
9

Three of eleven foster care and independent living case files did not meet this
requirement.
File one: Quarterly passports were not updated from March 2020 to June 2021. The
6/22/21 passport did not have the parent’s signature.
File two: A quarterly update was missing for June 2021.
File three: A medical passport was on file for 12/11/20. No quarterly updates were
completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
11/18/20 RENEWAL review, CAP approved 12/21/20
FOM 802-1 Psychotropic Medication In Foster Care
Pages 10-11
The DHS-1643, Psychotropic Medication Informed Consent, or
the prescribing clinician's alternative consent form that contains
all the required elements of the DHS-1643 as determined by the
FC-PMOU, must be used to document this discussion between
the prescribing clinician and the consenting party. Either form
must be completed in entirety, sent via email (encrypted for non-
state employees) to the FC-PMOU mailbox or faxed within five
days of receipt of the form.
One of three independent living files did not have informed consent documented for
several psychotropic medications.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency was reminded to ensure all foster home visit contact entries
include the information required for quality home visit standards in FOM 722-
06H, page 2.
 The agency was reminded to ensure the education tab in MiSACWIS is
updated with required information at the end of each school year per FOM
723, page 8.
 Case contacts- several foster home visits were entered as “case contact”,
which limits the ability to search for visits in MiSACWIS. The agency was
reminded to mark the proper identifying information for all contacts.
 Family Team Meetings- all 1105 reports should identify on the first and last
page, who attended and how they attended. If someone is not present in
person, the signature page should indicate the name and “attended via
phone/zoom”.
 Licensing renewal applications- the agency was reminded to ensure that all
foster home renewal notification letters indicate an application is enclosed.
 PATP signatures- Some PATPs held the required signature, but the signature
was undated. Therefore, it could not be verified that the PATP was signed
within the 30-day requirement. The agency was advised to check dates with
signatures before uploading to MiSACWIS. If a parent refuses to sign or
10

cannot be located, the worker should write refused or unable to locate on the
signature line, at the 30-day mark.
 Signatures- The MDHHS Policy office recently clarified that PATPs and
Medical Passports need to be signed by any non-respondent parent that has
placement of their child. This non-respondent parent must sign as the
‘placement provider’. As this was previously unclear in policy, missing
signatures were not cited. However, the agency was advised this expectation
will be required going forward.
 Sibling visits- The agency was reminded that sibling visits occurring on the
same date as parenting time, need to be entered as a separate ‘sibling visit’
contact, in order for data to correctly reflect the visits that occur. If sibling
visits are not occurring, an exception should be completed in MiSACWIS.
 FTM 1105 reports- The agency was advised that policy requires the 1105
report to be uploaded within 7 days of the family team meeting.
 YAVFC and Independent Living- the agency was reminded that YAVFC is a
legal status. Youth with a legal status of YAVFC have different placement
types, but are often that of Independent Living. Therefore, the agency is
required to follow IL licensing rules for all YAVFC youth residing in an
Independent living placement.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period. A special evaluation was initiated by the agency in March 2021
due to an allegation of improper discipline. Upon investigation it was determined the
foster parent hit a child with a shoe. A violation was established, and a CAP
developed. Documentation in the file confirmed the CAP was completed in May
2021. Overall, the agency appears to have completed a thorough investigation and
addressed the violation appropriately.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP approved 12/21/20 was the
result of the renewal evaluation dated 11/18/20. During this review the agency had
17 violations, compared to 20 violations in the 2020 renewal evaluation. 5 of the 17
were repeat violations from 2020. While the agency reports sufficient implementation
of the CAP and has shown improvement in many areas, there continues to be areas
that need attention. However, it was noted the agency underwent a significant
number of staffing changes, which resulted in new staff being trained, mentored, and
supervised virtually due to COVID. This appears to have impacted compliance in
some areas. With the development of a new CAP, and staff having gained some
experience over the past few months, the agency anticipates increased compliance
11

in all areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment indicated several challenges this year. In
addition to COVID and staff working remotely, there has been a significant staff
turnover including six experienced staff, a supervisor and other staff on medical
leave, an increase in caseloads, and the loss of some clerical support staff. The CA
reported delays in hiring new staff due to a limited pool of applicants. In the
meantime, to alleviate the caseloads, several cases were transferred to private
agencies. Despite these difficulties, the CA reported their CAP has been
implemented and the team completes regular internal audits to monitor for
compliance. Overall, the CA indicated the agency has shown improvement in many
areas. Although there are still areas that need attention.
Interviews
One foster care and one licensing staff were interviewed. Staff indicated there has
been some significant turn over this past year, which has been challenging.
However, they stated that hiring is in process and relief is coming. Both staff
reported working a combination of in person and remotely. Staff indicated the
workload is manageable once they learned how to balance working from home. Staff
stated their co-workers, supervisors and administration are supportive and
knowledgeable. Neither staff had any suggestions on areas of improvement for the
agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_ __________________October 27, 2021___
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
12

October 27, 2021
_______________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
